comment: The game is structured like an abstract and then has a dice element for randomisation of additional cube resources? Double layered majorities are an interesting idea, as is the collapse of the board into fewer regions but the randomness and length of game (60 minutes) mean this is not something I'd ever choose to play.

Counting up cubes and figuring out who even controls a region, it’s so goddamn tedious. And then rolling dice to determine your next actions, so it’s not even a diplomatic game. And the pain of having to recalculate EVERYTHING when cubes get added. Arrggh.

Games really downgraded after Catan. Even King is Dead is more fun than this, has less procedural steps.

A truly horrible game. The worst game I've ever played. The experience is absolutely broken in half by the randomness. If the knight refill was not random either player chosen or based on the result of the action you took there could be more game here. As it is you might as well just roll dice a few times to see who wins, save yourself 59 minutes, and play a better game. There are some interesting mechanics but in the three games I've played with three players I've seen one player completely locked out from controlling any colour despite not having placed any knights on to the board in two of those games.
I'm sure that I missed out on lots because it wasn't made clear during the teaching, but I just don't feel like I need to play this ever again.

Played 3 player. Choosing discs for turn order either felt chaotic if you weren't willing to permute, or tedious if you were. The dice would seem to add a pleasant information horizon to limit thinking ahead, but because they happen at the end of your turn, they contributed to a feeling of either frustration or obviousness at the beginning of your next turn.

For several turns in a row, I couldn't change the game in a way favorable to me, while others could, taking obvious advantages available to them. Then, when I built up the right majorities in my court, I forced other players to feel frustrated when they could do nothing to counter my advances.

It feels unengaging to be stuck, waiting for an opportunity to advance, and unpleasant to feel others' frustration when you can advance only because there's nothing they can do to stop you. It's undramatic. Where's the risk-taking? Where's the suspense?

I had high hopes after all the good reviews, but this game is definitely not my cup of tea. The chess-like permutation, the randomness being used to limit player interaction, and the lack of tactical and endgame tension are all deal killers. Considering my similar disappointment with Clans, I will be hesitant to play other Colovini games.

Comments: Carolus Magnus is an abstract strategy game about area influence and hand management. The ideia is players will use their cards to have the best position in the turn order and to move the Nature pawn. Then they will place tokens either on their own boards, to increase their influence in the colors, or on the islands, to have a stronger position there, once the pawn moves to that island. The first player to add all their control pieces to the main board, or have the most control pieces at the end of 10 rounds, will be the winner!

Carolus Magnus was alright, with the main decision point being: use the tokens either in the personal board, for increase influence in a color; or on the central board, to gain control of islands. I enjoyed the swingy nature, as island connect with each other when adjacent and controlled by the same person, which can lead to some big changes on pawns on the board when a big island is lost.

Overall, while not bad, with lean rules. meaningful interaction and good variation, I was mostly left cold, with little to keep me coming back and remaining interested; and this prevents Carolus Magnus from becoming much more than just a ordinary experience, with little left to remember afterwards; and unremarkable games are simply lost in the crowd.
Clever, old fashioned, but not one I find interesting enough to play more.

Feb. 2025 #33: I enjoy stock games, but I am often frustrated by their linearity. Your returns from a company are proportional to the number of shares you own, so gaining one more share doesn't change things dramatically, and your score is often closely correlated to another player's who has similar shares. This works to create runaway leaders and hinders large swings of fortune. Carolus Magnus (as well as The King is Dead, Pax Pamir 2E, etc.), on the other hand, allows for this by replacing linear stocks with majorities. If you have one more share in blue, you get all the benefits, not just a marginal increase. In Carolus Magnus, you might take over a color in one turn, grab a territory, pivot to a different color in the next, and rapidly consolidate into a win. This leads to a relatively short, highly dynamic game that's a blast to play.

Jan. 2024 #30: There's a mini-genre of "two-level area majority" games, including The King is Dead, Turncoats, and even Pax Pamir, but for my money Carolus Magnus (and the reprint Eriantys) is the best. It plays in under 45 minutes, but has huge potential for big swings and clever tactics. Some randomness in dice rolling is alleviated by playing the bag draw variant. Or, just play again!

2014.04.21 It's enjoyable and there's a lot of room for strategy and plotting. There's a definite social reading / theory of mind aspect involved in the selecting of the number discs at the beginning of a round. The turns move quickly: all you do is place three cubes and move the emperor token. But within that quick turn, you've got a great deal of swaying power. The area control battles feel Tigris & Euphrates-y, only more streamlined. The pacing feels right in that the game speeds up when things start getting dicey: since the 15 territories merge, near the end of the game you might have only 5 territories, meaning the emperor moves around them much more speedily. Really fun. (Based on a two-player session.)
